Leela helped Rasmus and the General devise their alternative plan of attack on Dalek-occupied Orrison after they seized control of the War Room from Ollistra, offering use of her Matrix slice to infiltrate the planet to disabled the temporal shield around it and obtaining weaponry from Narvin. She was accompanied by Rasmus and Veklin and was horrified to discover Orrison was now a production line for Berserker Daleks. They lowered the shielding but was informed by the General their timing was wrong and hundreds of TARDISes primed to attack had been caught in the shielding, destroying Orrison. They escaped back to Gallifrey via the Matrix, where Ollistra revealed she'd orchestrated the disaster to reassert her control of the War Room. (AUDIO: Ambition's Debt)

Learning of the War Doctor's mission to assassinate the Barber-Surgeon, Leela arranged for Narthex to be sent to assist him, giving him a pre-recorded message to show the Doctor. (AUDIO: The Abyss)

Leela fought with the Time Lords until the Battle of the Pillars of Consequence. There she was in charge of the retaking of Destilation from the Dalek Empire however was shot by a Disruptor Dalek, which displaced her in time and space.

After this, Leela gained "all her memories", being capable of remembering not only what happened to her, but also everything she could have done, and its consequences. Trying to remember what actually did happen to her caused her pain. She spent her time defending the universe from the Unlived, which came from a breach in time caused by a Dalek Temporal shift who was damaged. Despite her conficting memories, she still trusted the Doctor enough to allowed him to close the breach. She then went with the Doctor to Grend to stop the Daleks. The Doctor managed to heal her using the TARDIS. She could see that the War Doctor was still her Doctor. She wanted to defend Gallifrey. (AUDIO: The Lady of Obsidian)

On the way back to Gallifrey, she felt a sadness. She started to observe this enigma and thought it was sad. She saw the shadows of Daleks in the Capitol. After Lintok was affected by the Enigma, Leela helped her. She later thought that the Enigma was drawn to her. The Enigma started to talk through Leela. She could sense the Doctor's sadness and it used that to communicate with her. (AUDIO: The Enigma Dimension)

Leela was still serving as a commander at the end of the Time War. She observed Daleks attacking the Capitol from a nearby cliff and was delivered a wayfinder by a soldier, Axton, who told her it was from the Doctor and that he wanted her to escape. As Daleks including a red leader closed in, exterminating Axton, Leela defiantly told them it was not the end and activated the device, transporting herself to the Fourth Doctor's TARDIS. (WC: The Final Battle [+]Pete McTighe, The Collection (BBC Studios, YouTube, 2024).)

Having survived the apparent destruction of Gallifrey, Leela ended up a prisoner of the Z'nai, who had returned to power. While Leela lived on Gallifrey, the Time Lords had allowed her to retain her youth for a greatly extended time. This was no longer so. While the Z'nai tortured Leela for information about Gallifrey and the Time Lords, she aged physically, one year for each day.

The Z'nai had abandoned their ancient custom of leaving their chests bare. Just before the Z'nai interrogating her was to kill her, she gave him a choice — stop the killing or be killed. He laughed, but she infected him with the plague that had wiped out the Z'nai originally. The entire race died, leaving Leela and the other prisoners at first joyful, then terrified as they realised they were trapped and abandoned. Leela remained bound, without the strength to free herself, reminiscing about her days with the Doctor as she waited to die. (AUDIO: The Catalyst [+]Nigel Fairs, The Companion Chronicles (Big Finish Productions, 2008).)

After the Z'nai had all died and all torture had stopped, the machines used to torture Leela and her fellow prisoners kept them alive. Leela told a fellow prisoner who was crying a story about when she saw the Doctor being afraid. (AUDIO: Empathy Games [+]Nigel Fairs, The Companion Chronicles (Big Finish Productions, 2008).) Leela eventually died in the Z'nai prison. (AUDIO: The Time Vampire [+]Error: Code 2 - no data stored in variables, cache or SMW.)

Leela's soul was reborn as a young girl named Emily. Leela recounted many of her adventures with the Doctor to Emily. (AUDIO: The Child [+]Error: Code 2 - no data stored in variables, cache or SMW.)

Summoned to Gallifrey because of the Omega plots, the Fifth Doctor asked about Leela and was told by Damon that she was "well and very happy". He was sorry to have missed her wedding. (TV: Arc of Infinity [+]Johnny Byrne, Doctor Who season 20 (BBC1, 1983).)

The Doctor commented on the fact that Leela's child would be half-Gallifreyan and half-human. He told Leela to name the child after him. (PROSE: Lungbarrow [+]Marc Platt, adapted from Lungbarrow, Virgin New Adventures (Virgin Books, 1997).)

After seeing Richard Harries' experiments with rats, the Eighth Doctor recalled the episode in the London sewers when Leela had been attacked by a giant rat. (PROSE: The Banquo Legacy)

At some point, Leela was taken to the Black Archive by UNIT to have her record as a companion of the Doctor taken, she met Sergeant John Benton there. Leela's memories of the visit were subsequently erased and she was sent on her way. (TV: The Day of the Doctor [+]Steven Moffat, 50th Anniversary Specials (BBC One, 2013).)

After the Time War, the Tenth Doctor remembered Leela being the Lady of Obsidian and being lost in the conflict. Together with K9 Mark II, he encountered an alternative Leela created by the Spriggan, a malevolent version of himself from another universe. This Leela, who had believed herself to be the original, helped the Doctor to defeat the Spriggan. Leaving Leela with the Spriggan's TARDIS, the Doctor suggested that she could chose to rejoin the war and become one with her other self, among other possibilities. (AUDIO: Splinters)

Leela had a Bookface account and was friends with the Eleventh Doctor. She commented on one of the photos River Song tagged him in and asked if it was taken on Riftan Five, where she and the Doctor once got lost for three days. (COMIC: Timeliney Wimey)

When he first saw the comic book Amazonia, the Twelfth Doctor opined that Leela would have eaten the title character alive. (COMIC: The Fourth Wall)

Pragmatic, blunt, and fond of thinking with her gut, Leela stood in stark contrast to the modest, ladylike Sarah Jane. Even she knew this to a degree, telling Vince she was no lady. (TV: Horror of Fang Rock [+]Terrance Dicks, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1977).) As a creature of instinct, per the Doctor, (TV: The Invasion of Time [+]David Agnew, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1978).) she cared little for the requirements of polite society, ferally eating meat with Lightfoot, (TV: The Talons of Weng-Chiang [+]Robert Holmes, Doctor Who season 14 (BBC1, 1977).) and casually changing clothes in front of Vince, a stranger. (TV: Horror of Fang Rock [+]Terrance Dicks, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1977).) Her mindset proved a double-edged sword. While it made her confident she could survive anywhere, even the outlands of Gallifrey, she was only in the outlands because the Doctor, concerned she'd be susceptible to Vardan telepathy, ordered that she be banished there. (TV: The Invasion of Time [+]David Agnew, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1978).)

Though Leela joined the Doctor to learn about the universe, that didn't mean she submitted to his will. She used her weapons, particularly her dagger, however much he disapproved, (TV: The Robots of Death [+]Chris Boucher, Doctor Who season 14 (BBC1, 1977)., et al.), and she questioned him whenever possible, sometimes being exceedingly rude. She rarely ever conceded victory, only admitting she was mistaken to say the Doctor couldn't control the TARDIS when the TARDIS was endangered by a Relative Continuum Displacement Zone. Even then, it could've been wrong to do so. (TV: Image of the Fendahl [+]Chris Boucher, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1977).)

Leela believed the only way to learn was by listening to the wisdom of one's elders. (TV: Horror of Fang Rock [+]Terrance Dicks, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1977).) When she encountered a concept she didn't understand, which regularly happened thanks to the Sevateem's isolation, she would draw on her corpus of knowledge. Based on the noises made by a ship on the River Thames, she assumed it was an attacking swamp creature, (TV: The Talons of Weng-Chiang [+]Robert Holmes, Doctor Who season 14 (BBC1, 1977).) and the way in which the Fendahl travelled to Earth, using energy to project itself across space, was compared to lightning. (TV: Image of the Fendahl [+]Chris Boucher, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1977).) With regards to her tribe's superstitious views, she had room for improvement. While she knew Xoanon wasn't a god before meeting the Doctor, and she referred to the phantoms believed to reside beyond the Sevateem's territory as "feast fire stories", (TV: The Face of Evil [+]Chris Boucher, Doctor Who season 14 (BBC1, 1977).) she believed in magic until she was taught about science, and she sympathised with the Doctor upon learning he was frightened as a child by a mythological horror. (TV: Image of the Fendahl [+]Chris Boucher, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1977).) Still, she was quick to adapt to an intellectual life. In fact, she preferred it to an extent, telling Adelaide Lessage it was better to believe in science than in magic. (TV: Horror of Fang Rock [+]Terrance Dicks, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1977).)

Leela had a blase relationship with violence and death, the latter of which she didn't fear. (TV: The Talons of Weng-Chiang [+]Robert Holmes, Doctor Who season 14 (BBC1, 1977).) When a Chinese man implicated by her in a crime refused to talk, she insisted he be tortured into speaking. She celebrated her enemies' deaths, hoping a Rutan scout she wounded would enjoy passing away as much as she enjoyed bringing it to that state. (TV: Horror of Fang Rock [+]Terrance Dicks, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1977).) Even the elderly, unassuming as they usually are, were to be slain if they were crippled, maybe blind like her. (TV: Horror of Fang Rock [+]Terrance Dicks, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1977).)

It was clear Leela wasn't malicious by the kindly way in which she treated K9—nothing like the Doctor's dismissiveness towards him. When the Doctor opened him up to repair his corroded circuits, she petted him as if he were a flesh-and-blood dog, anxiously asking if he'd be all right. (TV: Image of the Fendahl [+]Chris Boucher, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1977).) She offered to listen to his spiel about Pluto, which he'd been prevented from giving by the Doctor, she expressed regret at leaving him in the TARDIS—the Doctor was adamant that he not visit Pluto with them—and she defended her right to refer to him with masculine pronouns, becoming pleased when the Doctor acknowledged her viewpoint. (TV: The Sun Makers [+]Robert Holmes, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1977).) Even when she lost her temper at him, telling him to shut up, upon realising she was why he was sulking, she softened and apologised. (TV: The Invasion of Time [+]David Agnew, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1978).) He more than appreciated her affection, choosing to stay with her on Gallifrey rather than keep travelling with his master. (TV: The Invasion of Time [+]David Agnew, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1978).)

Henry Gordon Jago believed Leela was the bravest creature he had ever met. (AUDIO: The Night of 1000 Stars [+]James Goss, Jago & Litefoot: Series Seven (Jago & Litefoot, Big Finish Productions, 2014).) Gesima Cazalet considered Leela an impetuous young lady. (AUDIO: Night of the Stormcrow [+]Error: Code 2 - no data stored in variables, cache or SMW.)

Leela admired Boudica. She doubted her knowledge of the Doctor's character after he refused to help the Iceni, saying "[she] thought [he was] a man of honour". Having ignored his warnings about altering history, she told Boudica of her coming defeat, and swore fealty to her. The slaughter at Camulodunon convinced Leela that she had misjudged the queen's character. She recognised her former self in Boudica and chose not to kill her when she had the chance. (AUDIO: The Wrath of the Iceni [+]Error: Code 2 - no data stored in variables, cache or SMW.)

On Gallifrey, Leela met Rodan. The Time Lady advised her to put her knife away, lest she hurt herself, which Leela said was something the Doctor often remarked. When Rodan allowed a fleet to pass and told Leela it was probably going to "blast some part of the galaxy to dust", Leela told her she ought to have stopped them, but Rodan explained that the non-interference policy forbade such action. Leela mocked Rodan's manner of speaking, saying "one must, one must, yes". Rodan only replied "I knew I'd like you" and turned off the force field that separated the pair.

For all that he lectured her and was offended by her aggression, the Doctor rather cared for Leela. He delighted in teasing her, telling her that the TARDIS wasn't interested in speaking to people with thought patterns like hers, (TV: Image of the Fendahl [+]Chris Boucher, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1977).) he became despondent when she mused on leaving him for Boudicca, (AUDIO: The Wrath of the Iceni [+]Error: Code 2 - no data stored in variables, cache or SMW.) and he became enraged at the No-Things when she was attacked by them. (AUDIO: Night of the Stormcrow [+]Error: Code 2 - no data stored in variables, cache or SMW.) When she departed the TARDIS to live with Andred on Gallifrey, such was his heartbreak, his response to her admission that she'd miss him was delayed and made inside the TARDIS. (TV: The Invasion of Time [+]David Agnew, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1978).)

Romana considered Leela to be her best friend. (AUDIO: Extermination [+]Error: Code 2 - no data stored in variables, cache or SMW.)

Leela considered Jago and Litefoot to be like family to her. (AUDIO: Chronoclasm [+]Error: Code 2 - no data stored in variables, cache or SMW.)

Leela was tall and strong with long, reddish-brown hair (PROSE: Doctor Who and the Invasion of Time [+]Terrance Dicks, adapted from The Invasion of Time (David Agnew (writer)), Target novelisations (Target Books, 1980).) and dark eyes, a broad, clear forehead and a firm chin. Her skin was tanned and smoothly muscular. (PROSE: Doctor Who and the Face of Evil [+]Terrance Dicks, adapted from The Face of Evil (Chris Boucher), Target novelisations (Target Books, 1978).) Due to pigmentation dispersal, her eyes became blue. (TV: Horror of Fang Rock [+]Terrance Dicks, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1977).)

Leela usually dressed in animal skins and armed herself with a knife and janis thorns. (TV: The Face of Evil [+]Chris Boucher, Doctor Who season 14 (BBC1, 1977).) She once accompanied this outfit with the Doctor's hat. (TV: The Invisible Enemy [+]Bob Baker and Dave Martin, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1977).)

While in London in 1889, the Doctor had Leela wear a less conspicuous outfit, befitting the time. Leela thought these alternate clothes were ridiculous. In order to affect a disguise, she took and dressed in Teresa's clothes.

In order to accompany the Doctor to the Palace Theatre, Leela wore a fashionable dress selected by George Litefoot. She was pleased by the comments the pair made, with Litefoot labelling it as "quite delightful" and the Doctor saying he would "be proud" to take her the theatre "looking like that". (TV: The Talons of Weng-Chiang [+]Robert Holmes, Doctor Who season 14 (BBC1, 1977).)

Leela dressed in a skirt and wore a boater hat for a trip to Brighton. When she found herself on Fang Rock instead, she changed into men's clothes belonging to the lighthouse keepers. The explosion of a Rutan mothership resulted in pigmentation dispersal that caused Leela's eye colour to change permanently from brown to blue.

While on Fang Rock, James Skinsale commented that Leela was "not a bad looker", but Adelaide Lessage thought her "perfectly grotesque". Skinsale told her he had learnt to "appreciate nature" during his time in India. (TV: Horror of Fang Rock [+]Terrance Dicks, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1977).)

Leela had skins in various tones and occasionally wore her hair in a bun. (TV: Image of the Fendahl [+]Chris Boucher, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1977).)

On Gallifrey, Andred helped Leela to choose an outfit. She went through many clothes, rejecting them all, much to Andred's annoyance. He asked her what outfit she would like and she replied: "a quiver, a bow, a pouch of Janis thorns and my knife back". While with the Outsiders, she wore a fur cloak over her other clothes. (TV: The Invasion of Time [+]David Agnew, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1978).)

After she stopped travelling with the Doctor, one of her skins remained in the TARDIS wardrobe. The Fifth Doctor's companion Peri Brown considered wearing it on one occasion. (AUDIO: No Place Like Home) The Eighth Doctor's companion Izzy Sinclair tried it once. (COMIC: Ophidius)

Leela was skilled in combat, both armed and otherwise. She was particularly adept with knives, which she used as throwing weapons. (TV: The Robots of Death [+]Chris Boucher, Doctor Who season 14 (BBC1, 1977).) Leela was able to hit a Sontaran's probic vent with a thrown knife and the Doctor congratulated her, calling the act "prodigious" and "amazing". (TV: The Invasion of Time [+]David Agnew, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1978).) Leela was once found by a policeman to be strangling her opponent with his own pigtail. She had never used a handgun until her visit to London in 1889, but managed to utilise it effectively against Mr Sin. (TV: The Talons of Weng-Chiang [+]Robert Holmes, Doctor Who season 14 (BBC1, 1977).) Leela told the Doctor that good marksmanship was not a matter of luck. After she knocked out Jack Tyler and used his shotgun to kill a Fendahleen, all the time being unable to look at her target lest it influence her, the Doctor agreed with her. (TV: Image of the Fendahl [+]Chris Boucher, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1977).)

Leela was skilled with a bow and displayed her talent for archery to the Outsiders on Gallifrey. (TV: The Invasion of Time [+]David Agnew, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1978).) The Doctor claimed that "Leela [was] an expert in armaments". (AUDIO: The Renaissance Man [+]Error: Code 2 - no data stored in variables, cache or SMW.) Before his death, Andred showed her how to operate a staser. (AUDIO: Extermination [+]Error: Code 2 - no data stored in variables, cache or SMW.)

Leela wrote with her left hand, but threw her knife and performed other actions with her right. (TV: The Invisible Enemy [+]Bob Baker and Dave Martin, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1977).) During her travels with the Doctor, he taught her to read and write. (PROSE: People of the Trees [+]Pam Baddeley, Decalog 2: Lost Property (Virgin Decalogs, 1995).; AUDIO: The Time Vampire [+]Error: Code 2 - no data stored in variables, cache or SMW., White Ghosts [+]Alan Barnes, The Fourth Doctor Adventures (Big Finish Productions, 2014)., TV: The Invisible Enemy [+]Bob Baker and Dave Martin, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1977).) However, she could not read English. (AUDIO: Beautiful Things [+]Error: Code 2 - no data stored in variables, cache or SMW.) She was able to swim and did so in the TARDIS swimming pool. (TV: The Invasion of Time [+]David Agnew, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1978).)

The Fourth Doctor told James Skinsale that "Leela's senses [were] particularly acute" when explaining how she had sensed a change in temperature that eluded everyone else present. Leela also believed she had a keen sense of hearing. (TV: Horror of Fang Rock [+]Terrance Dicks, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1977).) She could sense an evil about the Swarm and was able to tell that a communique from Titan Base had a non-human source. (TV: The Invisible Enemy [+]Bob Baker and Dave Martin, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1977).) Leela told the Doctor, after breaking the connection between him and Eustace, that she had felt something was wrong and had followed the feeling allowing her to find him. (TV: Image of the Fendahl [+]Chris Boucher, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1977).)

In Jack Corrigan's house in Kent in 1895, she was able to "smell" death and correctly predicted that a battle had taken place there. She also recognised that Henry McMullan was "not what he [seemed]" by being in his presence and hearing him talk. (AUDIO: Destination: Nerva [+]Error: Code 2 - no data stored in variables, cache or SMW.) The Doctor believed that her "tracking skills [were] peerless". (AUDIO: The Renaissance Man [+]Error: Code 2 - no data stored in variables, cache or SMW.) On another occasion, he described her as "the greatest hunter who has ever lived". (AUDIO: Black Dog)

After taking Ted Moss prisoner, she told him that "your Council should choose its warriors more carefully. A child of the Sevateem could have taken you". Later, she was able to move swiftly to avoid harm when Moss fired a gun at her, pressing herself against the outside wall of the Tyler cottage when he fired through the doorway from within. She disarmed Moss and turned the weapon on him, telling him the shot would be his last, and only surrendering the weapon when she believed Jack Tyler had a gun to her back. Moss told Leela as he left that he would see her later, to which she replied that he should get some practice first. (TV: Image of the Fendahl [+]Chris Boucher, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1977).)

In an alternate timeline created by the Sirens of Time's meddling with the first TARDIS flight on Henlen, the Fourth Doctor and Leela travelled to Henlen investigating temporal disruption. They encountered remnants of the pilots who attacked them, killing the Doctor. Leela was distraught at his death and stood against the remnants alone. This was erased when Romana, Leela and nine incarnations of the Doctor completed the flight. (AUDIO: Collision Course [+]Guy Adams, The Legacy of Time (Big Finish Productions, 2019).)

In an alternate timeline accessible via the Axis in which it was standard policy for the Time Lords to sell their temporal technology to the highest bidder and regenerations could be extracted and sold, Leela and K9 Mark I accompanied the Doctor on his search for the Key to Time. She was the only human to hold the Key to Time in her hands. Consequently, when her counterpart from the proper timeline visited this alternate Gallifrey, she was appointed Lady President. (AUDIO: Reborn)

In another alternate timeline accessible via the Axis in which the Time Lords regularly altered history through the Temporal Intervention Agency, Leela was brought to Gallifrey to amuse the then Lord President. She subsequently murdered Interrogator General Narvin and assumed his position under Lady President Romana. When her blind counterpart from the proper timeline visited this alternate Gallifrey, she took great pleasure in torturing her. (AUDIO: Disassembled [+]Error: Code 2 - no data stored in variables, cache or SMW.)

In a timeline created when Leela was flung to the planet Nateus by the War Master, she was born on Nateus and was known throughout her life as 'Leela of the Teus'. She had a son, Sholan, who becomes the corrupt 'Lord Warrior' after she saves him from a cliff fall, and is manipulated into conquering the planet by Zeno, militarising the Teus so they can aid the Time Lords in the Time War. Leela from the original timeline supplants her counterpart and undergoes time shifts, and she ensures that Sholan dies in the cliff fall in order to alter the timeline and thwart Zeno. (AUDIO: Mother Tongue)

In an alternate timeline within the Beyond, Leela died during an alien attack on Gallifrey. Her death drove President Romana to order the destruction of an entire Cannavar system to strike back against the enemy. (AUDIO: Beyond)

Leela was first conceived by producer Philip Hinchcliffe and script editor Robert Holmes. They wanted someone in the mould of Eliza Doolittle from George Bernard Shaw's play Pygmalion: a bright but unsophisticated primitive who would learn from the Doctor. Writer Chris Boucher had submitted a story proposal entitled The Mentor Conspiracy. It featured a character named Leela which fitted Hinchcliffe and Holmes's ideas.

Although The Mentor Conspiracy was not produced, Boucher reused the character of Leela for The Day God Went Mad (later renamed The Face of Evil [+]Chris Boucher, Doctor Who season 14 (BBC1, 1977).), seeing her as a mixture of Emma Peel from The Avengers and Leila Khaled. Boucher was asked to write two endings to the story, in one, Leela left with the Doctor and in the other she stayed behind. The decision to have Leela become a companion was made soon after.

Initially, Leela was to have only appeared in three stories. It was decided later she would stay for the remainder of season 15. One consequence of this decision was a plot contrivance added to Horror of Fang Rock to allow the character's eye colour to change, so actress Louise Jameson would not have to wear uncomfortable coloured contact lenses.

Jameson felt that Doctor Who's writers sometimes neglected to write for Leela as an individual, instead writing her as a stereotypical "Doctor Who girl." For example, in Underworld [+]Bob Baker and Dave Martin, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1978)., the script originally had Leela screaming when overwhelmed by poisonous gas. Jameson declined to do this, pointing out that it was not in character for the warrior Leela. (INFO: Underworld [+]Bob Baker and Dave Martin, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1978).) In fact, Leela screamed in only one television story, The Talons of Weng-Chiang [+]Robert Holmes, Doctor Who season 14 (BBC1, 1977)., when her leg was being gnawed by the giant rat — a scream which Jameson felt was justified. (DCOM: The Talons of Weng-Chiang [+]Robert Holmes, Doctor Who season 14 (BBC1, 1977).)

Leela ranks as one of the most violent companions, regularly threatening or using deadly force against other humanoids (often to the Doctor's disgust as in The Invisible Enemy [+]Bob Baker and Dave Martin, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1977)., but occasionally not as in Underworld [+]Bob Baker and Dave Martin, Doctor Who season 15 (BBC1, 1978).). Although other companions sometimes killed (for example, Romana I shot a guard in The Pirate Planet [+]Douglas Adams, Doctor Who season 16 (BBC1, 1978).), others have killed in spin-off productions (most notably Jack Harkness in Torchwood) and Ace racked up body counts in the New Adventures novels, Leela remains, to date, the only TV companion to be shown killing on a frequent basis.

Along with Irving Braxiatel, the Master and Jack Harkness, she is one of only four characters to play a major role in two audio spin-off series: Gallifrey and Jago & Litefoot. Leela and Braxiatel have both also appeared in the Main Range of Big Finish Doctor Who audio stories as a result of their guest roles in the audio story Zagreus. Leela also appeared in the main range story Time in Office [+]Eddie Robson, Main Range (Big Finish Productions, 2017)..
